a or an before H?: Use “an” before a silent H as with an heir, an hour, an honest politician, an honorary consul. Use “a” before an aspirated H as with a hero, a hotel, a historian.
Etcetera: write as etc without without It should be written as “etc..” when at the end of a sentence.
e.g. and i.e.: use this form and always follow with a comma
Oxford comma: generally, we don’t like oxford commas unless essential for clarity.
Semi-colon for lists: Use at you your discretion
Quoting Speech: All speech should be in double quotes
Quoting thoughts in interviews: single quotes
Quotes and full stops: full stop inside and outside when quote at the end of the sentence and a full quote.
A word in another language: use italics if not commonly used.
Dash: Use an EM dash whether for parentheses or to separate groups of words. Don’t use a hyphen.
If someone trails off while speaking use “...”
Round brackets: used as parentheses only when the sentence doesn’t make grammatical sense without.
Square brackets: used to inset missing words
Prefixes and suffixes: See commonly used words
